newsitem.title: UK: Ukraine offers debt to German banks - paper.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine offers debt to German banks - paper.

text.p: Ukraine is trying to sell some of its rescheduled debt to German commercial banks, including Deutsche Bank, a British newspaper said on Wednesday.
The sale could be for up to $350 million, the Financial Times newspaper said, quoting Ukraine's central bank governor.
The sale would take pressure off the country's foreign currency reserves, which would otherwise be used to pay the first part of the $1.4 billion of debt due this year.

The rescheduled debt was issued in 1995 to cover outstanding debt to Russia's Gazprom and is not available on the secondary market. Deutsche Bank was one of several banks involved in talks to buy some of the debt, the Financial Times said.
On Tuesday, Ukraine's central bank said it was working on a debut Eurobond issue. It said last year it hoped to raise $250 million in the capital markets in the first quarter of 1997.
Ukraine was expected to resume talks soon with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for receipt of a $2.5 billion three-year loan.
